While there are some things that I would like to see changed (or at least have the option to do so), this app is BY FAR the best option available for anyone who is seeking to have a MacOS style dock, and more crucially, a persistent MacOS Finder-style system menu bar at the top of their screen(s).

Believe me, I have tried just about every single alternative that exists that I could get my hands on over the years -- from RocketDock to heavily customized RainMeter themes -- MyDockFinder is hands down the most  fully-featured, comprehensive and best looking of the bunch.  If you're a super nerd like me (and let's face it, if you're reading this review, you probably are), then you'll totally love the extensive customization options available here, from changing the system tray icons and font face on the 'finder', to customizing the per-monitor (if you have a multi-monitor setup) behavior for showing/displaying the dock and/or finder, etc. you can really geek out on this and make it indistinguishable in it's appearance and mostly (about an 8/10) in it's functionality, to that of MacOS.

I'm sure there are people out there who are thinking to themselves, "why not just get MacOS?", which is a valid question -- unfortunately some of us are stuck on Windows due to workplace obligations or other necessities of life, and thus, this is the best we've got for recreating the elements of MacOS some of us love.

Don't hesitate to buy this, worth every penny.  BTW, the people who are posting comments/reviews saying that this is some kind of 'malware' or 'spyware' simply because a Chinese company had a part in developing it, are low IQ clowns and not worth listening to.  Not only does Valve check over the apps that are being sold on here, but I've personally gone through the source code to the various executable files and components to this app in a hex editor and have found nothing remotely sketchy in it.
Great functionality for the price, helped  me switch from windows to mac

Pros:
 - Very close to Mac OS

 - Probably the best Win10/11 Dock option I've tested

 - The Icons being built into Steam Workshop makes it super easy to find new icons rather than having to download packs

Cons
 - Occasionally crashes, not enough to be a huge bother though

 - Navigating through different windows seems to be a bit more tedious than vanilla windows, making it a bit more annoying while I am working with 50 things opened at once

 - Since the explorer task is always running in windows, you never know if you have a file explorer window open or not because the icon always displays as running. This is slightly annoying for me but not a huge deal

- I wish I could display the currently playing song right on the finder bar instead of having to click into the now playing button. Similar to how droptop 4 displays it would be a really nice feature for me personally.

 - This is a big one for me: PLEASE ADD THE WEATHER! I would love to have a weather temp readout in the finder.. I think droptop 4 is honestly a better finder than this but I decided to use this just to have all settings and appearances match.

Not sure why this app received so many negative comments lately...
It's really easy to use, it gets some time to setup initially, but that's what we're here for right? To tune the system to your preferences. And... it does the job! Developers did an amazing job granting wide control over customizations... you can customize the look and feel so it would be even better than the Mac (trust me, I use both).

After finishing customization - I got the best of two worlds, better visual look and interactions + functionality and flexibility of Windows. I can't be more happy, I was looking for the app like this for a long time!

Thanks developers! Worth every penny.

Very nice Dock for sure. Most of the docks out there were developed looooong ago. Many during Windows XP. There are a few newer ones (NexusDock) but they almost never update it. I paid for a 1 year free update service and they never did an update. Kind of a scam. The other ones Object Dock, Rocket Dock, RK Launcher, and others were developed long ago and may not run well for you with a current OS. MyDockFinder is a newly and actively developed dock and it receives frequent updates. The UI is clean, fresh, and professional. It has a ton of features, has a small footprint (0.7MB) and even has a setting to automatically exit the dock when playing full-screen games. You can also run the dock online or offline. Overall this is probably the best Dock right now considering all the features, the new code and continued development, and it's low cost. 
Added: Only negative is all the forum communication is almost all Chinese. And forget communicating with the developer unless you speak Chinese. They have also released updated that stop the dock from working. They seem to do little testing.  These are big negatives.

I own a macbook air m1 and spent the last 2 years using it as my daily driver for work. I recently purchased a gaming PC and moved my entire workflow to the PC but really missed the feel and flow of macos. This tool nearly completely replicates it. From the dock and menu bar to the ability to have a fully functional stage manager is incredibly impressive. Outstanding work done here by the developers. There are some quirks when it come to English translation but it's super easy to go and fix these things through the config files. Amazing app. If there was one thing I would wish for, it would be to have working notifications for all apps. Even if it just displayed the windows notifications in a  small menu icon with a count for them? Can't wait to see what new features get added next and excited to be on board for the journey!

It was nice and good at first (keeping a blind eye on Steam that kept tracing hours use...), but for layer issues and minor bugs I had to unistall this. And here's why something started to bother me: whether you unistall it through Steam or Windows, this thing leaves remnants of software and stays still and operative with upper toolbar and bottom icons BUT in chinese language. Obviously Control Panel struggled to show the program. I couldn't even find the execution file in task manager even by comparing the names inside the installation folder. This is where I started to really wonder what the heck is this program. 

First time in my life I had to use a third party unistaller 'cause I REALLY wanted to get rid of this real fast...
Now, maybe it's harmless, NOD32 didn't triggered, I use it for ages and I trust it blindly. 

But this is not how you code a program.

Slightly hesitant because of its mixed reviews and its partly Chinese description, which made me fear some parts of the app are in Chinese, I still took the plunge and bought MyDockFinder. What can I say: A fully-featured dock, including system-tray support (which vanished from other dock apps due to changes by Microsoft), plus a Finder and Stage Manager, which I didn't need but came to find very practical. Here's to hoping some settings will be refined and some smaller bugs ironed out.

* * * MyDockFinder is the most close Mac OS Dock and Finder for Windows. Is the best actually.

Advantages: 
-Simulation of mac effect when minimizing windows and other animations).
-option to add Finder bar (mac or linux style)
-Finder bar is great and has good features

Disadvantages: 
-Lack of proper troubleshooting support, no proper support for queries in western languages (English, etc)
-Dock and Finder customization not intuitive (user needs to know a bit about file structures, etc)
-No tutorial (western language) for users to make modifications and themes

First off - addressing some people's concerns regarding potential malware: straight up bull. 2/50 reports in VirusTotal is not indicative of anything other than false-flags. As for the app itself - very much a work in progress, but probably the best macOS UI replication available on Windows as of now. The dock behaves very much like Latte Dock in Linux.

Needed fixes:
1) Dock - Better multi-monitor-support: Minimize animations aren't applied correctly on my 2nd monitor (apps there are minimized to the Windows taskbar instead).
2) MyFinder (Global Menu) - Stability: This is very much alpha software, and crashes are frequent. As of now, I recommend you to disable this feature, if an uninterrupted workflow is your main concern. 
3) MyFinder - Features: The global menu seems to be using pre-coded presets for specific apps, such as Firefox and Windows Explorer. Less known/used apps lack this functionality, and simply fall back to displaying the app title and nothing else. Added support for user-generated "app modules" would go a long way to fix this, and would allow the community to add global menu support for third-party apps.

All in all - probably the best dock replicator available on Windows right now. It behaves very much like the real thing. MyFinder is still too early in development to be used in a serious work environment, but I look forward to further bugfixes and features.

(I would also like it if this app was available outside of Steam, perhaps in Microsoft Store. I very much like to separate gaming from my workflow, if possible - thanks).

Screenshot (Dock, MyFinder disabled - used with Start11 taskbar):
[img]https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/2027217558441884500/0D5A410F7EECC9C09BE0CFBAC5BAFA1CACCD6258/[/img]

This is a program with a UI written in Chinese, and the translation in some parts of the menus and UI aren't as clear or intuitive as it should be. When it works, it's like a charm. But it's a work in progress that requires patience from the user to try to master it. Some behaviours change from update to update and there's no tutorial in English, so don't expect any kind of support. You're on your own.

I've been using this for about half a year now and it is hands down one of the best pieces of software I've ever bought in terms of productivity. There's a lot of software out there that sets out to do similar things to this, particularly when it comes to docks, but they always feel poorly implemented and kind of "tacked on" as a layer on top of the windows environment. This one however seemlessly integrates with everything and feels like it could just be part of the OS.

It also comes with a whole bunch of other neat features, like the launchpad and most importantly to me personally the ability to have the dock(taskbar) on the bottom while having the tray at the top, it just feels very natural to use.

But most importantly though, we're getting very consistent updates and each major update always adds some cool new functionality. Yeah there's the occasional bugs, but they generally get fixed pretty fast so I don't consider that to be a big negative.

Let's talk about the advantages of dockfinder, the transparency effect of this app is very nice( compare to other windows-based software), and some small features can really amaze me.
However the stability of this paid software is so poor, even the opensource "latte dock" perform better than this.
If you are very concerned about appearance, and can accept the software crashes caused by under-optimized code, various small impersonal aspects and content-deprived workshop, it is worth a try

The scope of the software is great and if everything works as intended it is marvelous.
However, the app constantly crashes, sometimes even refusing to open. We're talking here at least 5 times during a normal day. It doesn't even prompt an error message and the error logs are non-existent.

Furthermore, it has no multiple monitor support. Technically it works but the GUI constantly switches from monitor to monitor whenever there is a focus change and there is no way to have it stick to one or all displays.  It has caused my computer to crash multiple times and it's a huge load on your graphics driver.

Don't buy this. Try using Cairo desktop interface. While it's not as streamlined as dockfinder and even tho it's doing more of it's own thing rather than ripping of gnome, It's a far more stable shell replacement that has all of the same features and then some.

----------------------------------------
Update: Since my review, some changes have been made to the software. There now is an option to stick the top bar to a specific screen. While I would prefer it to be on every monitor available, this is a fix that works for the graphical glitching.

I am still using this software as I write this. However, in its current state, I cannot recommend this to anyone I know because the developers need to improve this app's integration with games and for users like myself with multiple monitors. I use this app a lot and love its functionality, although I want to see them break boundaries and make further improvements/additions.

Here are some of the problems I face: when my game is in the borderless window mode, the finder and dock disappear. Hovering on the top and bottom edges won't work as neither the dock nor bar will appear.

When I make videos full-screen on my second monitor and go to focus on a window on my first monitor, the myfinder bar pops up on the second monitor, which is distracting and takes up space.

The auto-hide option for the myfinder bar only works on the primary monitor. If you try hovering your cursor at the top of any secondary monitor, the bar will not appear.

Regarding the first problem, I think the developers should find a way to let users access the myfinder bar or dock on the same monitor as a fullscreen game, and these facilities should auto-hide when not in use.

As per my second problem, I have a myfinder bar option enabled where it appears on all monitors. However, if I have a game or video set to fullscreen, I would prefer it where the myfinder bar or dock would appear when hovering my cursor at the edge of the screen.

Lastly, for the third problem, the auto-hide function for the myfinder bar should be in effect across all monitors. When the user hovers over the edge of any monitor, these bars should show up again and not just on the primary monitor.

If the developers were to fix all the problems above, I would change my recommendation from a no to a yes.

Been using this app for months, and as someone who's always preferred the MacOS look and feel over Windows, this is by far the best app for it, hands down. 

Unlike every other app I've tried that "tries" to bring to some Mac look over to Windows, this blends seemlessly into Windows 11, like I've have no issues with the top bar, or the dock interfering with my games or programs, it has no impact on my PC's performance either. 


I also love the features the devs added, such as customization, so if you just like the MacOS style (ie top bar + dock) but DON'T want to have the icons that make it look like a bootleg Mac, then you don't, like I use a Win11 theme for it instead of a MacOS Monterey one for example. Or if you don't want the top bar, you don't need it if you don't want it, change the font to whatever you want, or set your own custom icons on the dock. 

The addition of the Launchpad is also a very welcomed one, I hate having a cluttered desktop, so I threw my most used icons onto the dock and other lesser used apps/games onto the launchpad and it's so much easier to find and makes the PC look cleaner. 

Overall, the devs did a fantastic job on this app, and I think it's probably the best app I've ever bought tbh.

Great software that lets you have a nice looking dock which stores every icon you want.

The only thing that I would like the developer to implement is the "Layering" option with two options.

The two options are:

Always on Top - makes the dock always on top of any program you run (if you run, for example, Google Chrome, the dock will still be visible and will not go away).

&

Always on Bottom - puts the dock below every program (similar behavior to the taskbar, for example, run Google Chrome and the dock won't show itself even if I put my cursor on top of my screen).


I know many of you will probably say that this is already in the program, but my problem is that if I set the Dock Display Mode to "Smart Hide" or "Auto Hide", the dock will still show itself if I put my cursor on top/bottom of my screen, making the, for example, search bar unusable).

Either the Layering option or just an option to Disable the Automatic Reveal of the Dock when you put your cursor on the position where the now hidden dock (Smart Hide or Auto Hide) is located would be fine.
